column1: Many states require waiting periods between provider counseling and the abortion procedure. These mandatory waiting periods may require a woman to make two trips to the health care provider if the state requires the woman to receive counseling in person (as opposed to telephone, video call, or another avenue).
All states waive mandatory waiting period requirements in a medical emergency or when the woman's life or health is threatened.
Guttmacher Institute, State Policies in Brief, [Counseling and Waiting Periods for Abortion](http://www.guttmacher.org/statecenter/spibs/spib_MWPA.pdf), as of October 1, 2018.
1. In Alabama, the counseling requirement is waived in cases of ectopic pregnancy or severe fetal impairment.
2. Abortion-specific requirements follow established principles of informed consent.
3. Enforcement temporarily enjoined by court order; policy not in effect.
4. In Georgia and Rhode Island, the counseling requirement is waived in cases of medical emergency.
5. In Kentucky, a woman may be able to use telemedicine for abortion counseling.
6. In Louisiana, 24 hour waiting period is temporarily enjoined.
7. Enforcement permanently enjoined by court order; policy not in effect.
8. The law prohibits the inclusion of weekends and annual state holidays as part of the waiting period.
9. Enforcement of a provision of the Tennessee law requiring that a woman be told that an abortion constitutes major surgery is enjoined.
10. In person counseling is not required for women who live more than 100 miles from an abortion provider.
11. In Utah, the counseling requirement is waived if the pregnancy is the result of rape or incest or the patient is younger than 15.
12. In Utah, a woman may obtain abortion counseling in person at any medical office in the state.
